;言论自由消亡的所有迹象——无论是反抗议浪潮2020 年夏季后全国各州议会通过的立法，或者被广泛引用的民意调查显示言论自由不是年轻人的首要关注点——没有什么比围绕合法言论自由的相对沉默更令人担忧的了。过去一个月里爆发的危机。

;

;美国生活的几乎每个角落都感受到了寒意。周二晚上，众议院投票谴责唯一的巴勒斯坦裔美国国会议员拉希达·特莱布 (Rashida Tlaib) 关于加沙战争的言论;，包括放大“从河流到海洋”这一短语。在企业界，有一个;奇怪; ;多行业运动;，要么谴责现有员工，要么拒绝雇用参与抗议或签名支持巴勒斯坦的人员。

;

;媒体行业发生了大量解雇、辞职事件，并仓促实施了关于员工发表政治言论的新政策。其中包括;解雇生物医学科学杂志《eLife》主编迈克·艾森;，在他转发了《洋葱报》的一篇讽刺文章后； ;编辑 David Velasco 被解雇-;艺术论坛;;主席，在他签署并发表了一封信，表达了对巴勒斯坦解放事业的声援并呼吁立即停火；以及《泰晤士报》的;辞职;;特约撰稿人贾兹明·休斯 (Jazmine Hughes) 违反新闻编辑部政策，签署了一份不同的巴勒斯坦团结声明，《纽约客》的几位作家也签署了该声明。 （eLife 董事会在一份声明中表示，除其他事项外，它对艾森的社交媒体使用表示更广泛的担忧。） ;赫斯特杂志;也采取了真正严厉的举措;打击员工在社交媒体上发表的任何政治言论;，包括“点赞”其他人的帖子。

;

;在新闻媒体中，这些类型的谴责执行这些任务的人和机构将其视为必要的家务活——一种体现客观性的方式。 （其中一些是可以理解的：记者遍布全球的大型新闻编辑室对员工的政治言论可能会给同事带来困难有合理的担忧。）但纪律处分最好被理解为那些损失惨重的机构的绝望行为。他们塑造公众舆论的权力。对其使命的正义性充满信心的强大媒体组织不需要将员工作为愤怒暴徒的牺牲品。他们不需要隐藏在针对“政治”言论的薄弱的语义规则的后面，这些规则限制和压制了他们自己的记者，但却几乎没有让外部观察者相信他们是真正公正的。新闻独立性——不受外界影响的事实报道——不能是一种公共关系或人力资源活动，也不能通过承诺停止发布有关“政治”的推文来维持。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;我们大多数在该行业工作的人都知道这一点。很难找到真正相信社交媒体政治言论的谴责会导致新闻编辑室中立的人。我想，大多数人都相信他们的前同事完全有能力有尊严、细心地完成自己的工作。尽管对于明确的政治声明是否会损害媒体机构的诚信，或者所发表的声明是否对冲突中丧生的人足够敏感，存在真正的分歧，但强大的行业会将其转变为持续和透明的对话，并且这不是一种自上而下的审查行动，带来的问题远多于答案。

;
;
;

;这些惊慌失措的决定是在一些人所谓的“主流媒体”之间出现分歧的时候做出的。 ”而且公众明显扩大了。这种分歧是非常真实的，但没有一个相关术语能够真正被定义。当这么多人通过各种社交媒体帖子获取新闻时，到底什么才是主流？如果这种未定义的大众媒体确实存在偏见，那么它会倾向于哪种方式？

;

;回到;诺姆·乔姆斯基;和爱德华·S·赫尔曼写道“;制造同意;”，他们 1988 年对“大众媒体”及其如何传播宣传和压制异议的研究，美国人的平均新闻饮食由晚间新闻和一两份报纸组成。随着时间的推移，可以形成意见，并可以在竞争激烈的市场中做出选择。例如，如果您住在北卡罗来纳州，并且发现自己对《罗利新闻与新闻》感到恼火，观察家;，您可以拿起《北卡罗来纳州独立报》，或者在极少数情况下，您可以去当地图书馆阅读《纽约时报》。在更广泛的背景下，这些选择可能是虚幻的，但它们反映了真实的消费者选择，消费者非常认真地对待这一选择，并相信它代表了他们自己。

;今天，那些隶属关系已经沸腾了到少数传统媒体，最著名的是福克斯新闻和;泰晤士报;。前者造成了党派分歧，并且没有为向观众提供他们想听到的内容而做出太多道歉。 《泰晤士报》当然有自己的捍卫者和批评者，但它的功能与福克斯新闻有点不同：因为《泰晤士报》被视为最具传奇色彩的新闻媒体，它也同时成为批评“主流媒体”的支点。每一个错误的推文标题、每一个可疑的措辞以及报道中每一个可能的偏见都会被剖析，然后作为媒体所有错误的证据而传播。专栏作家发表的表达一种观点的观点文章成为整个报纸的替代品，即使不同意见被印在同一页上。

;

;因此，这些传统媒体已经受到几乎难以忍受的大量审查，这反过来又在新闻编辑室和管理层内部造成了存在主义焦虑。确实，批评的严重性可能是不公平的：《时代》评论版可以打印十张，每面五张，每个人都会发誓其他人的比分是 9-1。确实，这些传统媒体的编辑、记者和制片人无法让大多数人相信他们的报道是平衡的、客观的，或者你可能提出的任何其他模糊标准。;

;问题在于，新闻编辑室的负责人并不真正知道该怎么办。在这个混乱的时刻，这些机构中的许多机构都争先恐后地制定看似随意的政策，解雇人员，却很少考虑所有这些争先恐后的行为会对记者的士气或公众对他们自由报道能力的信任产生什么影响。以真实的方式表达自己。你可以要求你的记者在公众面前表现出清醒、压抑的态度，进行几次高调的解雇，并希望时间能神奇地回到你脑海中的过去，记者们在那里工作。公众根据您提出的可信事实进行了一场热烈的、相互尊重的辩论。那些时代——如果曾经存在的话——早已一去不复返了。维护自由和独立的新闻界仍然至关重要，但要做到这一点，就需要媒体公司的经营者将这种想法从封存状态中拿出来，并相信公众不希望压制任何“政治”表达，而是希望建立一个强有力的媒体公司。以及健康的讨论，其中所有的分歧都会引导我们走向真相。 ♦

;周二，Cherelle Parker 在钣金工人大厅登台宣布她当选为费城第一百任市长。帕克现年五十一岁，身穿红色蕾丝动力套装。 “上帝是好的！”她向观众喊道。 “每时每刻！”人群爆发出阵阵欢呼声。 “很多竞选专家认为他们会告诉我们应该如何走路、说话和行动才能赢得选举并获得选票，”帕克身边站着她 11 岁的儿子兰斯顿和她的政治导师前市议员玛丽安·塔斯科开始说道。 “感觉不太对劲。”

;

;11 月 7 日，帕克以 75% 的选票轻松击败了共和党候选人、前市议员 David Oh。真正的竞选是在去年春天的初选中，一开始，她的前景看起来很暗淡，对手包括知名度更高、资金更充足的候选人，其中包括在帕克左翼竞选的城市控制者丽贝卡·莱哈特(Rebecca Rhynhart)，以及社区的海伦·吉姆(Helen Gym)。组织者和进步宠儿，获得了 ;伯尼·桑德斯; 和 ;亚历山大·奥卡西奥-科尔特斯;。

;

;“我不是那些人中的一员，”帕克告诉我。 “我不是一个撤资者。我不是左派。我认为其中很多都是废话。”相反，她以直言不讳的中间派身份参选，承诺让费城变得“安全、清洁和绿色”。在第一次市长辩论中，她表示反对取消对警察的资助。她是唯一支持拦截搜查警务的民主党候选人，根据宾夕法尼亚州美国公民自由联盟分析的数据，这对费城黑人产生了不成比例的影响。她还提议该市再雇用三百名警察，《费城》杂志;被称为;“倒退”和“浪费。”

;

;去年夏天，我在凯利格林排屋外遇见了帕克，她的曾祖母当时住在那里她还年轻，在草莓大厦。 “如果你不知道我来自这里，你就无法理解我对某些政策举措的热情，”她告诉我。七十年代，草莓大厦是黑人工人阶级的主要社区，居民们种着颜色协调的天竺葵和凤仙花盆。 “这里没有人富有。但每个人都有足够的东西，并且渴望照顾好自己所拥有的东西，”帕克说。但是，随着费城成为全国最贫穷的大城市，这个社区变得年久失修。人行道弯曲了，她小时候擦洗过的家门前台阶上的绿色油漆剥落了。 “在竞选过程中，当我谈到擦洗台阶时，年轻人看着我，就像在问‘她穿什么衣服？’ ”帕克笑了。

;

;在门廊上，帕克的五位家庭成员——两个阿姨和三个表兄弟姐妹——都是女性——坐在那儿听着。他们时不时地闯进来嘲笑帕克，当她的表兄弟第一次预测她将成为市长时，帕克才八岁。 “她不停地说话、说话、说话、说话、说话，”帕克的姨妈玛琳·特赖斯说。 “哦，宝贝，她会说话了！” Trice 穿着一件爱心小熊 T 恤，上面写着“小心，我脾气暴躁”，她是“爱心厨房”的创始人兼首席执行官，这是她于 2005 年在帕克地下室创办的一个食品储藏室。 of Love 服务由老年人领导，他们每周出现 3 次，时间为凌晨 4:30;AM;。一盒三十磅的花生酱、金枪鱼和蔬菜，还有一块两磅的奶酪。“我不要求提供身份证明。没什么。如果你排队，你就需要它，”特赖斯说。她环顾四周，看看他们老邻居的情况。 “看看那些垃圾，”她嘟哝道。 “我们可以整夜坐在外面，把门开着，然后去商店，”她解释道。 “现在你连门都不敢来了。”

;
;
;
;
;
;

;

;帕克带我去草莓大厦是为了表达一个更重要的观点。 “我从小就知道政治只是一种用来决定如何分配稀缺资源的工具，”她告诉我。 “如果我没有看到我的税款在我所居住的社区发挥作用，那么这个流程又如何发挥作用呢？”她不满地看了一眼垃圾遍地的街区。 “我看到玻璃，我看到垃圾。我没有看到生意兴隆。我不想让我的孩子去公园玩，因为公园里有针。我不想让他在那里打篮球。”

;
;
;

;一个陌生人走过，对帕克喊道：“我为你走到了人行道上！”她身着黑衣，在去餐饮工作的路上，自我介绍为托莎·泰勒(Tosha Taylor)，一位社区组织者，在初选期间曾为帕克上门。 “这不仅仅是她想要做出改变的事实，”泰勒说。 “这是我感觉到的事实。”泰勒是十个孩子的母亲。 “我把十个人都养大了，”她告诉帕克。 “我教他们如何清洁，我教他们如何做饭。我教他们如何成为社会的模范人物。”通过烹饪学校，她找到了摆脱无家可归和住在庇护所的出路。现在泰勒开始相信，贸易学校可以消除代际贫困。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;当泰勒走开时，帕克告诉我，“这里的家庭勉强维持生计，不得不在支付电费、喂养孩子或确保他们有地方之间做出选择为了活着。这是一种惊人的不公正。”她接着说：“如果你是一名民选官员，你倡导的每一项政策都必须直接影响社区人民的生活。而且它应该是有形的。他们应该能够看到它、触摸它、尝到它、感觉到它。”她又看了一眼这个街区，说道：“黑人的命也是命——但每次我走出家门，它都是脏的？”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;费城 150 万居民中近一半是黑人，他们意识到自己巨大的政治权力。 “黑人在电视和手机上看到他们的选票在 2020 年很重要，”州代表唐娜·布洛克 (Donna Bullock) 告诉我。 “这就是为什么这么多人试图通过跨越州界线并在车里放枪来阻止计票。”费城的黑人选民可以通过参加民意调查来决定 2024 年总统选举的结果——令许多人惊讶的是，帕克关于公共安全的信息引起了这些选民的共鸣。 “切雷尔是最早提出黑人确实希望执法部门参与使我们的城市更安全的人之一，”州参议院议员谢里夫·斯特里特告诉我。 “我们只是希望他们做好自己的工作。”

;

;帕克的批评者认为她的想法是危险且不合时宜的。她的许多建议，例如安装监控摄像头和扣押非法车辆，都属于“破窗”理论，该理论可以追溯到十九世纪八十年代，并将退化的自然环境与较高的犯罪率联系起来。几乎没有可靠的证据支持这一理论，但它的受欢迎程度仍然存在。 “如果她追求‘打破窗户’，这些可怕的倒退政策就会失败，”废奴主义者法律中心执行主任、宾夕法尼亚大学法学院讲师罗伯特·萨利姆·霍尔布鲁克告诉我。 “一旦他们这样做，我们就会把她的政府告上法庭，这将使该市损失数千万美元。”

;
;
;

;上个月，帕克漫不经心地说道，作为市长，她将派遣国民警卫队在肯辛顿的街道上巡逻，这里是该市阿片类药物流行的中心。 “Cherelle Parker has this idea she's going to bring the National Guard to chase drug addicts up and down Kensington Avenue, but they're not trained to do that,” Holbrook said. “Any slipup on their part reflects on her.” (Parker later walked this comment back.)

;

;Philadelphia is one of the most segregated cities in America, with white residents remaining in traditionally Irish and Italian American enclaves, Black residents isolated in the poorest neighborhoods, and a centuries-old history of racialized law enforcement. But attitudes toward policing don't break down along racial lines, in Philadelphia or elsewhere. “There is a white-liberal fallacy that people of color are against the police,” Michael Nutter, who served as Philadelphia's mayor from 2008 to 2016, told me. “That's not true. They're against police brutality.”

;

;Nutter was a vocal proponent of stop-and-frisk, as part of a larger program of crime deterrence. As he put it, “Leave your gun at home, or you're going to jail.” But stop-and-frisk has a dismal history in the city. “When you look deep into the data, you find that ninety per cent of people stopped during stop-and-frisk are innocent,” David Rudovsky, a civil-rights attorney who has been practicing in Philadelphia for the past fifty years, told me. In 2010, Rudovsky sued the city for its unconstitutional use of stop-and-frisk, and, for the past decade, Philadelphia has been under court order to monitor the practice.

;

;Philadelphians remain divided in their opinions about the police. In 2017, they elected Larry Krasner as district attorney on a platform of ending impunity for law-enforcement officials. Krasner has since charged four officers with murder, winning the first recorded conviction against an on-duty Philadelphia police officer. His anti-mass-incarceration platform, including ending cash bail and decriminalizing low-level offenses, earned him Black supporters—and made him a polarizing figure in Pennsylvania politics. He was the subject of an impeachment campaign by Republican state legislators, and he's frequently accused by law enforcement of being “anti-police.”

;

;Parker has announced a zero-tolerance policy on misconduct by law enforcement, but she staunchly believes that policing plays a role in tackling gun violence. Her plan for proactive policing involves sending three hundred new officers out into ten neighborhoods, on walking or bike-riding beats. To defend her vision, she invokes the idyllic Philadelphia of an earlier era—where, she recalls, beat cops on foot were “guardians, not warriors.” (A spokesperson for Krasner said that the DA is “looking forward to working with the Mayor-elect” but expressed skepticism about Parker's proposals. “It isn't enough to just add more police officers to the department,” the spokesperson said. “We need them to actually show up, do their jobs, and follow departmental regulations, as well as the law.”)

;
;
;

;“I will not be bullied that I'm pro-police or not looking at the root causes of gun violence,” Parker said. “Anyone with two eyes can see we can't police our way out of this, but, whether people like it or not, public safety is part of the solution.” She added, “In the world I live in, the Black community wants stability and safety.” Parker takes herself as a case study: she is the mother of an eleven-year-old boy with an impish smile who lives in northwest Philadelphia. She wants the police to be better funded and present to help her son make it to and from school.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Parker defended her plans to increase policing by invoking her portfolio of successful policies for Philadelphia. She's worked in government since she was seventeen years old. “I'm not some Johnny-come-lately,” Parker retorted. “The city deserves proactive policing as part of a holistic approach.”

;

;Parker, who calls herself a member of the OAM, “the Old-Ass Mom's club,” named her son Langston, after her literary hero and a key figure of the Harlem Renaissance. (I first met Parker through her son, who attended second and third grade with my own.) “Langston Hughes represents dignity,” Parker told me. “I, too, sing America.” Her favorite poem, Hughes's “Mother to Son,” opens, “Life for me ain't been no crystal stair” and speaks to the challenges Parker has faced. “Every policy prescription I have is deeply rooted, to be quite honest, in pain that I experienced as a child,” she said.

;

;Her mother was sixteen when she gave birth to Parker, in Philadelphia; her biological father was rarely around. When she was eleven, her mother died; Philadelphia's mayor-elect was raised by her grandmother, a domestic worker, and her grandfather, a disabled Navy veteran, along with a larger communal network. “Sometimes your bloodline isn't enough,” she said. “You need your loveline. The loveline is the village.”

;

;To raise their granddaughter, her grandparents relied on ninety-eight dollars in cash assistance every two weeks, along with food stamps. “I hated that shit as a child,” she said. “Those food stamps messed with my confidence, but my grandmother would use reverse psychology and say, 'Oh, so those richer people are better than you?' ”

;

;Before the mayoral race, Parker had never told these stories in public. To her surprise, she found that her experiences resonated. “When you talk about food insecurity, I know what it was like to get a five-pound block of surplus cheese,” she said. As she described how the cheese didn't slice right, she watched heads nod.

;

;Parker was stunningly clear, however, that her personal biography wasn't intended to serve as an appeal for pity. “I wasn't a throwaway,” she said. “There was great expectation for me. Whatever I did, my grandmother and grandfather wanted me to do it exceedingly well.” The solution wasn't about outsiders “coming in to save—or feeling sorry for—Cherelle.” “No,” she said. “You wanna help Cherelle? Put her in an AP class.”

;

;For Parker, education provided a way out economically and intellectually. “Before I could fall in love with Shakespeare and Beckett and 'The Canterbury Tales,' and understand the value of those mainstream classics, I had to find a sense of self,” she said. Her favorite high-school teacher introduced her to African American literature. “When I talk about my best friends and role models Maya Angelou, Ntozake Shange, and Sonia Sanchez, people ask if I still see my teacher in church,” Parker said gleefully. “They are shocked to learn that she was a white woman.” She loves to confound easy assumptions, particularly regarding race. “My village was diverse,” she added.

;

;Parker's political career began in high school, when she won an oratory contest, based on a speech she wrote about the power of African American women's literature. The prize included a trip to Senegal. She also received an internship with Marian Tasco, the former city-council member and one of Philadelphia's most powerful Democratic politicians. Tasco taught Parker that the most important measure of a politician was the resources she brought back to her community—as Parker put it, “How are you using your politics to improve the recreation center?”

;
;
;

;Parker attended Lincoln University, a historically Black school in Chester County that was also Langston Hughes's alma mater. After graduating, she briefly taught high-school English in New Jersey, until Tasco recruited her as a staffer. “I viewed my students as being a part of me,” Parker said. “I didn't want them to think that I was quitting on them.” Yet Tasco convinced Parker that working in government would allow her to strategize funding for entire school districts, broadening her impact. In 2004, Parker became the youngest Black woman elected to the Pennsylvania House. She remained there for a decade, chairing the Philadelphia delegation.

;

;Pennsylvania's state capital, Harrisburg, lies only a hundred and five miles west of Philadelphia, but it reflects extremely different political concerns. Along the Pennsylvania Turnpike, a barn outside Harrisburg invites passersby to “;REPENT;” and serves as a reminder that Pennsylvania is home to fifty-two thousand farms. Yet, in Harrisburg, Parker proved highly successful in working with different contingents of her own party—as well as across the aisle—to craft economic policy that helped Philadelphia become more fiscally stable, cutting the deficit in the city's pension funding in half and implementing a cigarette tax to fund public education.

;

;“I couldn't say, 'If you don't agree with my ideology, I'm not gonna talk to you,' ” she told me. “We had to be willing to build coalitions of necessity.” Parker was also known for her outspoken defense of Philadelphia's needs, arguing successfully for homestead-exemption relief, which passed into law in 2023 and required wealthier residents to pay more taxes. “I was tired of seeing folks who lived in huge houses with pools on the Main Line pay nothing,” she told me.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In Harrisburg, Parker developed her power as an orator. “She told stories that made people visualize what it was to live as a single Black mom or as a young man returning from prison,” Donna Bullock, the state representative, told me. “Some folks warned me not to be her, because it made them uncomfortable.” Of the thousands of people who have served in the Pennsylvania state legislature, a small fraction have been Black women. Bullock told me, “It's a certain level of crazy to even want to put yourself in that situation.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Governing Philadelphia appears similarly daunting. Among major American cities, it's the worst in terms of poverty and crime rates. It also ranks fourth in the nation for deaths related to opioids, a crisis worsened by the introduction of fentanyl and xylazine, which is also known as Tranq, a veterinary sedative that is more addictive than heroin—and far more dangerous. The economic downturn caused by ;the coronavirus pandemic; struck Philadelphia particularly hard, and the city has been slow to recover, with joblessness rates nearly double that of the national average. “If anyone just looks at the city and all of the challenges, they'd say, 'Whoever wants to be mayor of this city is certifiably out of their mind,' ” Parker told me.

;

;As mayor, Parker will have to stanch the flow of money and people away from Center City, Philadelphia's urban heart. “This is what keeps me up at night,” Parker said, one afternoon in July. She'd convened a group of eight real-estate and other investors and union leaders in a conference room of the Cira Centre, a twenty-nine-story glass shard that sits across the Schuylkill River from Center City. Through the window, a statue of William Penn, who founded the Commonwealth in 1681, was narrowly visible atop City Hall. By law, Penn's statue once marked the highest point in Philadelphia. Now he was dwarfed by office towers, at least four of which were being boarded up.

;

;Gabe Morgan, a vice-president of the 32BJ Service Employees International Union, which represents ten thousand custodial and office workers in Philadelphia, spoke next. “Our members are afraid of vacant buildings,” he began. Approximately eight out of ten of their members in Philadelphia were working-class Black people, and, he noted, a vast majority had voted for Parker. Those workers relied on their jobs in Center City office buildings, which belonged to executives like Jerry Sweeney, the founder and CEO of Brandywine Realty Trust. Sweeney, who sat next to Morgan, runs a company with a large portfolio of Philadelphia real estate, including the Cira Centre.

;

;When Morgan and Sweeney typically met, they wrestled over contracts and terms as part of complex labor negotiations. “Two weeks from now, we'll be bargaining and I'll sound different,” Morgan said. “But, in partnering with business, we have to collaborate to save a huge job base that's not replaceable.” Parker was proud to have brought these two leaders together. “I've watched some constituencies thrive on creating David versus Goliath, as workers versus business. In my world, you don't pit one against the other,” she said. “When people are in office buildings, I see security guards and janitorial staff. These are the homeowners in the City of Philadelphia, who, because of their union membership, are earning a living wage.”

;

;Afterward, as Morgan rode down in the elevator, he explained why his union, which was considerably more left-leaning than Parker, had supported her from the start. She was a pragmatist, and the decisions she made reflected the bread-and-butter interests of his members. “Cherelle can look at things and say, 'I'm going to measure this by what helps people like me,' ” Morgan said. “And that's very different from being a white progressive.”

;
;
;

;The next day, Parker was in Kensington, the Philadelphia neighborhood hit hardest by the opioid crisis. The stretch of Frankford Avenue beneath the elevated train tracks was lined with storefronts, including Cash Express, which offers quick loans, and faith-based outreach organizations, like the Rock, which offers boxing and ministry. The sidewalk was strewn with discarded needles and occupied by colorful nylon tents; people in the throes of addiction slumped in beach chairs. One woman stood by a parked truck, using its side mirror to find a vein in her neck.

;

;Kensington's drug crisis grew more extreme during the pandemic. Those injecting Tranq, along with heroin and fentanyl, are often covered with open sores, which can become so severely infected that users are prone to losing limbs. The harm-reduction movement argues that it might not be possible to get people off these drugs, but that safe-injection sites can lower rates of death and infectious disease, as well as the amount of drug paraphernalia on the streets.

;

;In 2018, a local nonprofit called Safehouse proposed opening a safe-injection site in Philadelphia. “I've visited such sites in New York and St. Louis, and what I've seen is people getting access to health care and social-work services,” Kendra Brooks, a city-council member from the Working Families Party told me. Parker is vehemently opposed to them, fearing that safe-injection sites will perpetuate the sale of illegal drugs. “Someone called me anti-science, but that's bullshit,” she said. “When you've had loved ones suffer from addiction, the last thing they needed was a safe place to do the drugs.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That morning, Parker—who campaigned on building thirty thousand new housing units—was visiting a red brick warehouse in Kensington, a defunct paper-archiving facility recently converted into some two dozen low-income lofts. A local community-development corporation, Impact Services, had cobbled together twenty-four million dollars for the project, a combination of low-income tax credits, public and private funding, and government loans.

;

;“This twenty-four million is not based in ideology,” Parker told me, in the pristine multipurpose room. “It's based in people who are going to work to make this possible.” Parker gestured toward Bill McKinney, of New Kensington Community Development Corporation, and Casey O'Donnell, of Impact Services. O'Donnell explained that this development strategy was designed to protect residents against displacement, by rehabilitating their houses and organizing civic groups. At the request of those residents, they'd cleared Hope Park, a rare green space in Kensington, which until recently had served as an open-air drug market and tent encampment. They'd partnered with the city to bulldoze the area that had served as a toilet and built a fancy new gated fence, to which residents now had a key. After surveying from the community, they wouldn't be leasing commercial space to methadone clinics or other businesses that serviced addiction and recovery, a decision Parker applauded. “Communities are drained of life by these places,” she said.

;

;Parker had invited along Marnie Aument-Loughrey, a Kensington resident since 1970. A local ward leader, Loughrey recalled that, during the primary campaign, she'd told Parker, “I love you, but I can't support you unless you come out here and do a walkaround.” So Parker did. “No police, no extra entourage,” Loughrey had said. She wanted to show Parker how little the city had done to support longtime residents. Loughrey's thick accent recalled a generation of white, working-class Philadelphians who lived in Kensington before the crack epidemic, in the eighties. She wasn't afraid to flash her old-school credentials, including an admiration for Frank Rizzo, the notorious mayor who is sometimes called the Donald Trump of Philadelphia. (During his reign, in the seventies, police officers killed one civilian a week on average.) “I'm not ashamed to say it,” she said. “I don't fight for me—I fight for my community.”

;

;“No one is going to decide what's going to happen for the people in Kensington and the people of Kensington not be a part,” Parker said. She proceeded upstairs to one of the soon-to-be occupied lofts. Peering out of a picture window, Parker talked about “affordable luxury”: amenities like high-quality appliances that represent the dignity with which people like to live. She was skeptical of tiny houses—one solution that housing activists were proposing for Philadelphia. If a sense of ownership was related to pride and space, who aspired to a doll's house? “Maybe people want to be crammed into a tiny house, but I don't think we need to lowball expectations,” she said.

;

;“Black women are the backbone of the Democratic Party,” Bullock, the state representative, told me. “We are behind every labor movement, women's movement, and the civil-rights movement. If you look at it, Black women have been doing the work all the time. And now we're also getting the opportunity to lead.” One afternoon in August, Parker invited a group of twenty-some Black women organizers to meet up at Coffee Cream and Dreams, a Black-owned coffee shop about a mile from Fairmount Park. Many were members of Cherelle's Corner, a woman-led effort to support Parker, with the slogan “We've Got Her Back!” Some had known Parker for decades as friends and fellow grassroots political leaders.

;

;“This right here is a group of women who I still get daily texts from,” Parker told me, scanning the crowd as she entered. Settling into a seat at one of the café's tables, which had been pushed together into a U, Parker invited each participant to introduce herself and name her principal concern for Philadelphia: trash, support for business owners, mental-health services, and so on. The group was ecstatic that Philadelphia was likely to elect its first woman mayor. “My organization is predominantly white females,” Vanessa Fields, the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the National Organization for Women, said. “These white girls overwhelmingly wanted us to endorse Cherelle!” Another gushed about Parker's fashion sense: “I know we're talking about all these policies, but when Black girls and Black women see you show up sharp in the hood, with your shoe game always on point, that means something to us.” A third, a stranger to Parker, said that she became a supporter while in the bathroom at her mother's house. Through the bathroom door, she could hear Parker booming a speech across the street— “Don't let anybody put shade on your shine!”—and she was hooked.

;
;
;

;Amid the joyfulness, one concern kept coming up: gun violence. So far in 2023, more than a thousand people have been killed by guns in Philadelphia. Chantay Love, one of the founders and president of ;EMIR; Healing Center, a community counselling organization, shared her account of watching violence spike early in the pandemic. Love turned to every city and state official she knew, trying to find more funding for her counsellors; she didn't know Parker personally, but Parker was the only official who responded. A retired reporter with the Philadelphia ;Tribune;, a Black newspaper that has been operating continuously since 1884, spoke of how demoralizing it had been to advocate for gun safety since her son was murdered, fifteen years ago. “I have rallied in the streets, and I'm tired,” she said. She was inspired by Parker's plans to use law enforcement, including a ;SWAT; team, to address the scourge. “I thank God for you, Cherelle Parker,” she said. “And may He continue to cover you with His blood.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;So far, some three hundred and thirty people have died in gun-related violence in Philadelphia this year. Laron (LJ) Williams, who was killed on his twelfth birthday, June 22nd, was one of the youngest. Two months after his death, Parker went quietly to a community-development office in Germantown, a neighborhood founded by William Penn in northwest Philadelphia. In a cramped, windowless office with Muhammad Ali posters on the wall, she met with Williams's mom, Michelle Brister, who sat at a tiny round table, wearing overalls and looking stunned. “I read that Laron was called the mayor,” Parker said to Brister—he was known as the “soul of the neighborhood,” gregarious and ubiquitous. “I'm not the mayor yet, but I'm here to learn about the challenges facing the city.”

;

;Parker didn't reach for Brister's hand or offer promises impossible to deliver. Instead, she chatted with Brister about how the neighborhood had changed since the days when Brister and Parker had come up spending their time after school at cheerleading practice. “I was a West Oak Lane Wildcat,” Parker said. She asked Brister what might keep kids safe. Would it help to have police walking a beat? Brister shook her head. They already had police in cars in Germantown. She thought that the most critical change would be to open rec centers, so that kids had somewhere to go after school, instead of tooling around on their bikes in the street and making trips to the corner store for snacks—which is what Laron was doing when he was shot. Brister had opened the door to find her son, who had been trying to reach the house, dying on the front steps. She'd recently found the Ruffles he'd had in his hand when he'd died, and his bike was still in front of the house. “I put air in the tires in case anyone wanted to ride it,” Brister said.

;

;Outside, on Chew Avenue, Parker shooed her team away, to prevent them from photographing her talking to Brister. She hates social media—as well as any narrative that casts her as the answer to problems she is unlikely to solve. “I am no savior,” Parker told me. “I never promised the City of Philadelphia that I would ride in on a white horse.” ♦

;On Wednesday night, the actor Jeremy Allen White, of “;The Bear;,” was working his way down a red carpet in Dallas. It was the première of “The White Claw,” an A24 movie about the Von Erich clan of professional wrestlers. On the carpet, an “Entertainment Tonight” reporter ;informed White;, “We just heard moments ago—the strike is over!” and stuck the mike in his face. “That's amazing,” White said, seeming taken aback. Asked how he felt, he added, “I don't know the details of the deal, but I'm sure that ;SAG; got what we wanted.” Since mid-July, when the actors' strike began, the sight of celebrities such as White and his co-star Zac Efron traipsing red carpets has been rare; actors were barred from promoting projects connected to major studios and streamers. White and Efron were in Dallas only because “The White Claw” received an “interim agreement”—an exception given to indie projects abiding by the guild's proposed terms, and one of those bits of technical jargon that became Hollywood parlance over the tumultuous last few months.

;

;The ;SAG;-;AFTRA; strike lasted a hundred and eighteen days, and overlapped with the Writers Guild of America's ;strike;, which began in May and lasted a hundred and forty-eight days—the first time both guilds had been on the picket lines simultaneously since 1960. Back then, the central issue was residual payments for movies replayed on television, a relatively new phenomenon for a relatively new medium. This time, a technological change once again upended how entertainment is consumed and, subsequently, how actors are paid. Instead of the birth of television, it was the birth of streaming. Actors who were used to living off residual payments from network roles between gigs had found themselves receiving paltry checks for equivalent work on streaming shows. In July, on the cusp of the strike, I ;spoke; to cast members from “Orange Is the New Black,” who said that they had never truly shared in the wealth the series generated for Netflix, even as the show helped build the foundation of the streaming economy. Although the final deal still has to go through approval formalities at the guild, and the fine print has not yet been released, ;SAG;'s hard-won agreement includes performance-based bonuses for actors on streaming shows that become big hits. For the studios represented by the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, or AMPTP, the concept was a non-starter before the strike. Now it's Hollywood's new reality.

;
;
;

;But the issue that unexpectedly came to the fore, as it did for the writers, was ;artificial intelligence;. In August, as Hollywood was entering an ;end-of-summer malaise;, I spoke to a professional background actor named Vincent Amaya, who appears in a lot of police procedurals. “I do not want to be scanned,” he said. “They can use my image and then always have me crossing in a cop station without paying me. That's my livelihood.” AI is still a vast unknown, but both guilds saw it as an existential threat. In ;an interview; this week on the industry podcast “The Town,” Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, the guild's astoundingly named national executive director and chief negotiator, said that the final sticking point had been the use of “synthetic performers,” or what he termed “synthetic fakes”—essentially, nonexistent people remixed from real ones. (Perhaps you've seen footage online of normal-seeming extras who, on closer look, have ;eight fingers on one hand;.) ;SAG; wasn't fighting to stop the AI revolution but for its members to receive “informed consent” and compensation when their images are used. Once again, a new technology preceded a labor upheaval.

;

;On “The Town,” Crabtree-Ireland described the mood in the negotiating room as “cordial” but “serious,” with occasional flareups. In 1960, the actors' strike was led by none other than Ronald Reagan, who went on to become one of the country's more ;anti;-union Presidents. This time, the guild president, working alongside Crabtree-Ireland, was Fran Drescher, whose idiosyncratic style, known to fans of “The Nanny,” will be inextricable from this chapter in Hollywood history. When the talks broke down during the summer, she gave an impassioned speech excoriating the industry's CEOs and accused the studios of giving the guild “a ;leck; and a ;schmeck;,” Yiddish for “a lick and a sniff.” When the two sides finally started meeting again, in the fall, reports spread of her unconventional tactics, such as bringing a heart-shaped plushie to the bargaining table. Perhaps this was Drescher's answer to Richard Nixon's “madman theory”: throw off the enemy with an ounce of ;mishegoss;. Earlier this week, the ;Hollywood Reporter; ;asked;, “Will she be remembered as an eccentric scene-stealer or a fiery labor iconoclast?” I'd say both. Or, as the theme from “The Nanny” puts it, “Who would have guessed that the girl we described was just exactly what the doctor prescribed?”

;

;Now, at long last, Hollywood can get up and running. Annette Bening can hit the Oscar campaign trail for “Nyad.” ;Ridley Scott; can finish “Gladiator 2.” We'll finally find out what happens next season on “;Severance;.” Stars can trade their picket signs for tuxes and gowns. And the countless crew members, costume designers, caterers, and agents who've been sitting out the past several months—often at dire financial cost—can get back to work. The industry they're returning to may be more equitable than it was, but that doesn't mean it'll be smooth sailing. The streaming economy had already been facing a reckoning, with Wall Street demanding profitability, and studios are tightening their belts and contracting production. As Brooks Barnes ;writes; in the ;Times;, “Most analysts say that there are too many streaming services and that the weakest will ultimately close or merge with bigger competitors.” No sooner did the strike end than the executive Jeffrey Katzenberg predicted that AI will reduce the workforce for animated films to less than ten per cent of what it is, and Warner Bros. shelved the completed film “Coyote vs. Acme” for a tax writeoff. Peak TV appears to have ;peaked;, and theatrical moviegoing is in crisis. What lies ahead is uncertain. But, as this historic year demonstrated, some crises are worth the trouble. ♦

;救护车刺耳的叫声，红蓝灯闪烁，宣告着Samira的到来阿尤布和她的三个孙女：14 岁的 Rimas、12 岁的 Talin 和最小的 Layan，只有 10 岁。他们回到了黎巴嫩南部小镇布利达的家，似乎所有居民以及议员和邻近城镇的人们都在主广场附近迎接他们。街道的一侧是穿着黑色罩袍和长袍的妇女，许多人手里拿着三个女孩的 A4 大小的肖像。他们向救护车上扔了大米、粉色和白色的九重葛花瓣。另一边站着身着制服的青少年和来自真主党伊玛目马赫迪童子军的男子，该童子军是黎巴嫩童子军联合会下属的一个青年组织。

;

;四具棺材从救护车上运出，高高地抬过布利达狭窄的街道走向墓地。女孩们的棺材上覆盖着印有童子军徽章的白旗，上面还放着花圈。他们祖母的衣服上披着黑色天鹅绒，上面绣着伊斯兰诗句。一辆装有扬声器的皮卡车铺平了道路。当游行队伍经过一片橄榄园时，一名手持麦克风的年轻人高呼：“以色列去死吧！美国去死吧！”

;

;周日晚上，一架以色列无人机烧毁了他们家的汽车，导致四人死亡。以色列国防军后来告诉《以色列时报》，他们击中了一辆“载有几名恐怖分子的可疑车辆”。里面没有男人。女孩的母亲霍达幸存下来，目前仍在医院接受治疗。他们的父亲马哈茂德在非洲工作。 （黎巴嫩严重的金融危机在 2019 年震惊了整个国家并持续产生影响，迫使许多黎巴嫩公民到国外赚钱。）他回到布利达参加葬礼。

;

;在墓地，马哈茂德哭了当他把头放在女儿的每一个棺材上时。 “我亲爱的，我的生命，你就是我的生命，”马哈茂德一次又一次地说。他自己的父亲就站在他旁边。扩音器里，一名男子正在谈论加沙、抵抗以色列、保卫土地、国际法的双重标准和胜利，而马哈茂德则平静地、伤心地向女儿告别。 “这些是我的孩子，”他对周围的人低声说道。 “你孩子怎么样？看看我的。我的孩子们在天堂。没有人会再问我他们怎么样了。”

;

;我在葬礼上遇到的当地英语老师拉尼娅告诉我，“在这之后我们就什么都不确定了。我认为回应将会很艰难。抵抗组织必须采取行动。”她指的是真主党。

;

;萨米拉和她的孙女在同一天被杀，在黎巴嫩南部其他地方，一架以色列无人机袭击了两辆救护车附近，造成四名护理人员受伤。 （以色列国防军表示，它的目标是一支“恐怖分子小队”。）以色列对平民和紧急车辆的袭击标志着当前冲突的危险的新升级。然而，对于许多黎巴嫩人来说，这感觉就像是似曾相识。 2006 年，七月战争（以色列人称之为第二次黎巴嫩战争）爆发后仅几天，就有 23 名平民（其中许多是儿童）在逃离边境附近的小村庄马尔瓦欣 (Marwahin) 时在以色列的空袭中丧生。其他类似的罢工也随之而来。救护车也成为攻击目标。

;
;
;

;以色列和真主党之间的最新一轮敌对行动于 10 月 8 日开始，即 < a href="https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/israels-calamity-and-after">;哈马斯在以色列的毁灭性伏击;。联合国划定的黎巴嫩和以色列边界（被称为“蓝线”）自 2006 年战争以来一直相对平静，但现在在不断升级的日常暴力冲突中再次陷入战火。至少有 10 名黎巴嫩平民被杀，其中包括一名路透社记者，还有两名以色列平民。

;

;11 月 3 日，真主党秘书长赛义德·哈桑·纳斯鲁拉 (Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah) 发表了备受期待的讲话，赞扬了他考虑了黎巴嫩前线的成就：转移了本来可以用于入侵加沙的以色列军事资源，使以色列北部的数千名居民流离失所，并灌输了对以色列北部的恐惧。 newyorker.com/news/dispatch/the-simmering-lebanese-front-in-israels-war">;全面的地区战争;，他将这种情况描述为“现实的可能性”。他直接指责美国支持以色列在加沙的进攻，并警告说，任何更广泛的冲突都将成为美国利益的目标。 “八十年代初在黎巴嫩击败你们的人还活着，和他们在一起的还有他们的子孙，”他说。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;美国航空母舰的威胁——最近几周已将两个打击群转移到中东——也没有纳斯鲁拉表示，阿拉伯和西方外交官的请求将影响真主党的算计。只有两个决定因素：以色列在加沙和黎巴嫩的行动。他说：“凭借所有的诚意、透明度、明确性和建设性的模糊性，我们黎巴嫩战线上的所有可能性都是开放的。”他警告说，如果以色列针对黎巴嫩平民，真主党将遵循新规则，“以平民对付平民”。本周末，纳斯鲁拉将再次发表讲话，纪念在战斗中阵亡的真主党战士。

;
;
;

;萨米拉和她的孙辈遇袭数小时后，真主党向什莫纳镇发射火箭弹，以色列北部的一个小镇。 （已经大部分撤离。） 英语老师拉尼娅告诉我，布利达的一些人预计这将是一个转折点。她说，他们离开城镇是为了让真主党战士能够对以色列进行报复，而不会因平民的存在而感到受到阻碍。

;对战争扩大的担忧已经导致超过两万五千人逃离黎巴嫩边境地区，约有一万人在南部城市提尔寻求庇护。上周，提尔市危机管理管理局局长莫尔塔达·姆纳 (Mortada Mhanna) 与几名红十字会志愿者和市政工作人员坐在办公室的一张长桌旁。墙上有两个屏幕，一个显示半岛电视台的滚动新闻，另一个显示流离失所者的统计。他没有太多时间聊天。 “五分钟，可以吗？”他告诉我。他说，大多数流离失所者被安置在以前空置的公寓里或与亲戚住在一起，大约八百人被分散在四所作为避难所的学校里。 “我为一万人准备了六千张床垫，”姆纳说。 “每天，我们都必须为食物和床垫而战。”

;

;他已经捉襟见肘，而且资金不足，而且担心边境局势进一步升级，仅提尔地区就有十万人涌入。 “这比 2006 年更困难，因为援助像点滴一样到达，”他说。据联合国称，在 2006 年战争中，多达一百万人流离失所。如今，黎巴嫩的状况明显更糟，是一个因领导层空缺而陷入瘫​​痪的破产国家。该国已经一年多没有总统了。令人衰弱的金融危机使大约百分之八十的人口陷入贫困。人们都在努力养活自己，更不用说别人了。 “国际非政府组织并没有像我们处于战争中一样来处理这种情况，”姆纳说。 “我坐在提尔，我说我们正处于战争之中。边境地区正在发生战争。这是前线。”

;

;历史在被记录和重述之前，已经被二十五岁的萨拉·法拉杰 (Sara Faraj) 和她六十岁的母亲纳瓦尔 (Nawal) 等女性所生活和重温。 。他们来自南部边境的艾塔阿什沙卜村。 2006 年战争期间，萨拉还是个孩子，她流离失所，住在邻近 Rmaych 村的一所学校里。大约一个月来，她发现自己又回到了教室，这次是在提尔，现在和自己的孩子以及其他几位亲戚在一起。学校的底层住着来自几个边境村庄的其他十几户家庭，而一楼继续接待学生和正常上课。

;

;在 2006 年战争中，她村里的清真寺公开广播了一条信息逃跑。这一次，萨拉和她的家人没有等待。 “我们现在已经习惯了，”她说。 “我们立即决定离开。”他们什么也没带来。她的孩子们穿着捐赠的衣服。姆纳和他的团队已经在努力储存加热器和毯子，以备流离失所者在学校避难所过冬。莎拉六岁的大女儿不明白为什么她不能回家，并且怀念玩玩具的日子。 “他们做得不太好，”萨拉告诉我。 “他们在这里很无聊。我记得关于 2006 年战争的一切，所有的一切，但主要是恐惧，我担心这场战争会对我的孩子们造成什么影响。”

;

;Nawal 一边看着她的孙子们，一边吸着香烟。她的家在2006年的战争中被毁；随后，她用推土机推平了残骸并重建了它。还有更古老的冲突：以色列对黎巴嫩南部大片地区（包括她的村庄）长达二十二年的占领，于 2000 年结束。在此之前，在六七十年代，她记得“巴勒斯坦人会从我们的国家发射火箭”。村庄，以色列人将袭击巴勒斯坦人，”她说。 “这太可怕了。多么美好的回忆啊！我们还想要什么？我们的问题是我们出生在以色列旁边的这个国家。”

;
;
;

;在提尔的黎巴嫩德国大学，该大学有这些家庭也被改造成避难所，来自距离边境约一百米的 Dhayra 村。居民称，炮击已损坏了当地两打以上的房屋。据国际特赦组织报道，10月16日，以色列用含有白磷的炮弹轰炸了该村庄，违反了国际人道主义法。那次袭击后许多人逃离。据说村里只剩下不到十二人。

;

;上周，纳斯拉拉发表演讲的前一天晚上，最后一批坚持抵抗的人之一纳德·阿博·萨里 (Nader Abo Sari) 将他的红色拖车停在德国大学外。他没有留下来的意思；他来城里只是为了出售收获的烟草。他的拖车里塞满了长方形的粗麻布包装，里面塞满了干烟叶。他的妻子带着四个年幼的孩子来到更北的地方与父母住在一起，但阿博·萨里拒绝离开他的村庄，他觉得自己有义务照顾他的几头牛、羊和鸡，并喂养流浪猫和被遗弃的猫。动物。 “这些天总是很紧张，”他站在离拖拉机一段距离的地方说道。 “我醒来时不是听到祈祷声，而是听到炮弹袭击我们地区的声音。” 2006年，阿博·萨里表示，他在西顿市的一座清真寺寻求庇护，该市距离贝鲁特约半小时车程。这一次，他不会离开，除非“以色列人袭击村庄并将我赶出去。”

;

;几天后，我打电话给阿博·萨里，了解达拉的情况。他说，最近有四、五个家庭回到了家。 “人们已经受够了，”他说。 “他们厌倦了流离失所。这是战争，但不是战争。说这是平安，是为了心理上感觉更好——这不是平安。这并不让人放心。如果一个人想回来，并不能保证事情会平静下来或变得更好。而且，如果你想离开家，过上流离失所的生活，那是一种耻辱。”

;

;至于他的处境，他说他已经“适应了”，并开玩笑说导弹袭击打破了单调。的乡村生活。 “这就是行动，”他笑着说道，然后邀请他去达拉共进午餐。 “这会很棒，”他说。 “每年的这个时候，这个村庄都很美丽。” ♦

;鲍里斯·莫卡 (Boris Mocka) 相信，在某一时刻，他发明的领带结比地球上任何人都多 —如此之多，以至于他开始称自己为“领带专家”。大多数打领带的人都熟悉四手结，或许还有温莎结和半温莎结。但还有很多其他的：普拉茨堡、卡文迪什、汉诺威。 1999 年，两位物理学家出版了一本名为“;打领带的 85 种方法;。”然而，他们的统计还远远不够全面。 ;Mocka; 独自创造了更多超过一千五百节。栀子花看起来像一朵花； Wicker 和 Mockatonic 看起来像折纸。谜语者看起来像一个问号，而埃克苏西亚则需要不止一条领带。 “我非常痴迷于原创，”莫卡告诉我。

;

;莫卡不是物理学家，也不是男装设计师，而是我公寓楼的门卫。他的服装发明之路和他的丝绸作品一样曲折。他 1969 年出生于马提尼克岛，在巴黎长大。他的父亲在他两岁时就去世了，他的母亲搬到了纽约，没有他的陪伴。他被一个在空闲时间画画的人收养，并激励莫卡开始绘画。莫卡十岁时，人们告诉他，他的艺术技巧是上帝的恩赐。 “我们更清楚，因为这叫做实践，”他说。

;

;十一岁时，莫卡在纽约与他的生母团聚，她在那里为法国领事馆工作，他最终加入了联合国国际组织学校。他与母亲的关系紧张，他偶尔会逃跑并露宿街头。 （他们不再说话，也无法联系到他的母亲发表评论。）最终，他与雕塑家的一位家庭成员成为了朋友 ;克拉斯·奥尔登堡;，帮助他进入了一流的艺术学校库珀联盟学院。然而，在莫卡入学之前，他被征召入伍并被运送到马提尼克岛。他用头撞了一名教官，并在法属圭亚那的一个流放地度过了一段时间。服役只剩下一个月了，他想退役。他指定的精神科医生告诉他，以精神错乱为借口是唯一的选择，所以他这么做了。

;

;莫卡告诉我，当他回到纽约时，他一度无家可归并有自杀倾向。 “我在朋友家之间来回走动，直到我不再受到欢迎为止，”他说。 “我睡过火车，睡过楼梯。”为了赚点钱，同时也为了向自己证明自己可以打败任何人，他参加了地下裸拳拳击比赛，使用的是他在军队学到的法国跆拳道。 （他说他从未输过。）他在东村教授格斗课程，运送大麻，并担任搬运工。最后，他在第二大道熟食店工作了十年，在那里他遇到了妻子，并从清洁工晋升为经理，这使他能够租用自己的公寓。

;

;莫卡发明了他的第一个领带结2013年，他四十四岁。他的妻子怀孕了，他需要健康保险，所以他找到了一份工会工作，在他的一个朋友工作的公寓楼里担任门卫。第一天上班的前一天晚上，他熬夜学习打温莎结，希望能给人留下好印象。

;

;当莫卡上班时，他的朋友正准备回家。 “我太兴奋了，”莫卡告诉我。 “我一直在说，‘你没看到这有多酷吗？这是完美的温莎。 ”

;
;
;

;他的朋友对此不以为然。 “你知道，你可能想查一下埃尔德雷奇结，”朋友说。 “如果您访问 YouTube，您会找到视频。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Eldredge 结具有传统结的倒三角形形状。然而，三角形的表面被分成五个重叠的鞘，这使得结看起来几乎像辫子。在学习打领带的过程中，莫卡犯了一些错误。 “但我更喜欢这些错误，而不是结本身，”他说。他开始制作视频来跟踪动作。

;

;很快，莫卡发现了一个专门用于打领带结的在线社区。他发现了像墨洛温系结这样的结，该结以 2003 年电影《黑客帝国：重装上阵》中的一个角色命名；这很不寻常，因为尾巴在刀片前面打结，就好像领带系着一条较小的领带。在 YouTube 上，他开始关注领带传播者，例如加拿大房地产经纪人帕特里克·诺沃特尼 (Patrick Novotny)，他在社交场合会打不常见的领带结以脱颖而出。莫卡最终创作了一千多个自己的视频。他建立或阐明了数十种基本技术：扭转、旋转、盘旋、隧道、蜿蜒、展开。有时他会在半夜醒来，有了一个新的想法，然后哭着叫醒熟睡的妻子，“我明白了！”

;

;在打领带的小世界里，莫卡成为了一个小名人。一位多产的结设计师、南非法庭翻译马布·莱特索阿洛 (Mabu Letsoalo) 称他为天才，对他产生了重大影响。诺沃特尼的领带主题 YouTube 视频观看次数超过两千万，他告诉我，“我认为领带界的每个人都可能会向鲍里斯致敬，因为他发明了最多的结。”然而，这是一件非常难以裁决的事情。莫卡说，他联系了吉尼斯世界纪录，但该组织表示，要创造一项纪录太难了；它的所有记录都必须是可测量的、可打破的、可标准化的和可验证的。关系引发了疑问。领带上的任何结都是领带结吗，还是有规则的？你能简单地通过加捻或打圈将旧结变成新结吗？当你把两个结结合在一起时，它们会变成一个吗？这些不仅仅是美学问题，也是数学问题。

;法国

;;

;纽结理论属于拓扑学的数学领域，它探索数学对象的基本属性。拓扑学家将形状视为橡胶制成的。他们认为立方体和球体是一样的，因为一个可以在没有任何粘合或撕裂的情况下变成另一种。 （数学家有时开玩笑说拓扑学家无法区分甜甜圈和咖啡杯：每个都有一个孔。）根据拓扑学家的说法，结只是一个闭环。最简单的非平凡结是三叶结，它与上手结相同，但绳子的两端相连；在纸上，看起来就像有人画了三叶草。

;
;
;

;在他们的大部分历史中，领带结和结理论是并行发展的。领巾是围巾的一种，在欧洲流行了 1600 年，1828 年出版的《打领巾的艺术》一书包含了 32 门打领巾的课程。现代领带出现于十八世纪五十年代，除了时尚之外几乎没有什么功能。最初的四手结据说得名于一种驾驶马车的方式。十九世纪三十年代，较大的温莎结开始流行。它是以温莎公爵的名字命名的——尽管他实际上戴着四手制的，只是系着大领带。

;

;“拓扑”一词来自德国数学家约翰·李斯汀 (Johann Listing)，他在一本 1847 年的书。 1867 年，结理论又向前迈进了一步，当时物理学家开尔文勋爵受到他的同事彼得·格思里·泰特（Peter Guthrie Tait）吹出的烟圈的启发，提出了原子是以太中打结漩涡的理论。泰特很快就数出了所有有七个交叉点的结。 （有十五个。）虽然他们关于原子的观点被证明是错误的，但纽结的数学成为了它自己的专业。

;结仍然是一个棘手的问题。例如，数学家长期以来认为有一百六十六个结，有十个交叉点，他们使用表格来描述每个结。 1974 年，哈佛大学法学院学生 Ken Perko 浏览了其中一张表格，发现了一些有趣的事情：其中两个结是相同的。 （它们现在被称为 Perko 对。）在更高的维度中，事情会变得更加混乱，或者可能更少。三个维度的结在四个维度上解开；同时，在四个维度上，你可以打结球体。

;

;领带结的艺术和科学终于在九十年代开始融合，当时在剑桥工作的物理学家托马斯·芬克和毛勇了解到领带结是美国人杰瑞·普拉特发明的。一位服装商宣称这是“50 多年来第一个男士新结”。芬克和毛决定对领带结采取泰特对一般结所做的做法：对它们进行分类。他们在《打领带的 85 种方法》中写道：“显然，新领带结的发现是一件罕见的事情。” “我们没有再等半个世纪才下一个结，而是考虑了一种更正式的方法。”

;

;;

;象头神

;;

;将结理论应用于领带，首先想象领带的两端在打结后融合在一起，形成一个闭环。然后考虑一下，领带与传统的结不同，必须缠绕在人的脖子上并垂在他们的胸前。领口和悬垂感这两个特征使领带结成为自己的一个类别。根据标准拓扑，四手和温莎是完全相同的；他们只是三叶草。与此同时，半温莎和普拉特都是无结的——简单的戒指。但是，在实践中，这四个领带结是不同的。

;

;芬克和毛想象了一条领带搭在一个人的肩膀上，领带尾部（即窄端）位于左侧，而刀片（即较宽端）在左侧。 ， 在右侧。他们为刀片的移动方式创建了一种特殊的符号，以及有关顺序的规则。他们将领带结限制为九个动作，最后将刀片向上推向下巴，然后向下穿过一个环。使用他们的符号，在 YouTube 视频中需要几分钟才能解释的内容可以用一小串字符来表示。例如，四手牌是L⊗R⊙L⊗C⊙T：左进、右出、左进、中出、直通。他们认为，基于数学对称性和平衡性，他们的 13 个结在美学上令人愉悦。四把手、温莎、半温莎和普拉特都在其中；据他们所知，其他九个以前从未被描述过。

;
;
;

;Mikael Vejdemo-Johansson，拓扑学家现在在纽约城市大学，2013 年读过芬克和毛的论文。作为一名二十多岁打领结、最终开始打花结领带的数学家，他是他们的理想读者。然而，他发现他们的研究并不令人满意。芬克和毛泽东研究了仅具有平坦表面的结，这排除了更复杂的创造，例如埃尔德雷奇和墨洛温纪。 “芬克和毛基本上只是定义了所有有趣的事情，”Vejdemo-Johansson 告诉我。

;

;Vejdemo-Johansson 知道，你可以用领带做无数的事情。由于大多数领带结都太无聊或奇怪，所以你必须制定规则 - 但规则也不能太严格。他决定与几位合作者进行自己的关系研究。他们认为结最多可以有十三个动作，可以穿过多个环，并且不需要以与芬克和毛的结相同的顺序结束。他们还认为，尾巴而不是刀片可以起带头作用，这是像 Eldredge 一样打出复杂结的唯一方法。

;

;数学家和计算机科学家经常研究形式语言，它们有自己的形式语言有关顺序的符号和规则。 Vejdemo-Johansson 将他的领带结描述为一种独特的语言，具有自己的符号和语法。他和他的同事表明，他们的语法本质上比芬克和毛的语法更复杂，因为有些动作只能与其他动作结合使用：你必须先形成循环，然后才能将领带塞进去。但对于计算工具来说，枚举该语言中的所有“句子”或结并不太复杂。

;

;2015 年，该团队发表了一篇名为“;联系比我们想象的更多;。 ”他们的最终统计数字达到了惊人的 266,682。随附的网站 ;tieknots.how;，随机生成的结和教程。然而，由于研究人员没有应用任何美学规则，他们的许多结都很丑。数学尚未征服艺术。

;胸肌

;有一段时间，莫卡将自己的关系变成了一家小企业。只要花五十美元，你就可以寄给他一条领带，他会打个结然后寄回来。只要一小时两百美元，他就会给你绑一条。今年二月，Mocka 自行出版了一本五百页的书，“;如何打结; ”，其中解释了数十种技巧并给出了十六个签名结的说明；他以两百美元的价格出售精装本。但莫卡的创作期在 2015 年左右达到顶峰。他需要专注于养家糊口，而且他对领带粉丝在没有适当版权的情况下抄袭他的作品感到沮丧。一位设计师在听说莫卡想要创造发明最多绳结的世界纪录后，开始与他竞争，“制造出毫无意义的绳结，”莫卡告诉我。 “他们有点搞乱了比赛。”最后，他几乎将所有 YouTube 视频设为私有。

;

;6 月，我邀请 Mocka 和 Vejdemo-Johansson 到我的公寓，以便他们第一次见面。这位数学家首先到达，穿着蓝色实用短裙、正式背心和衬衫，打着三位一体领带结，这是一种现代经典，其外观分为三个对称的面板。他扎着马尾辫，留着灰白的山羊胡子。

;

;当时，莫卡在我的大楼里当搬运工；由于下班了，他没有穿着平时绣着“鲍里斯”名字的工作衬衫，而是穿着 T 恤和卡其裤。 （最近，他被提升为门卫，并开始打着花哨的领带结去上班。）他剃了光头，留着灰白的胡须，没有打领带。

;

;坐在我的餐桌旁，维德莫-约翰逊翻阅着莫卡的书。他显得很兴奋：“我已经能看到那些符号绝对看不到的东西了。”显然，其中的联系比“比我们想象的更多”所想象的还要多。

;

;“我不是数学家，”莫卡说。 “我其实是来看看我是否有妄想症。”他笑了，然后开始解释他书中的一些技术。

;
;
;

;Mocka的一些动作，Vejdemo-约翰逊说，增加了几何复杂性，但没有使结在拓扑上有所不同。其他人则增加了额外的交叉口。不管怎样，维德莫-约翰逊继续说道，数学还没有捕捉到它们。 Mocka 实际上发明了一种新的方言，其语法甚至比专业数学家使用的语法还要复杂。

;

;“你和我的操作方向完全相反，”Vejdemo-Johansson 告诉 Mocka。 “我的目​​标是选择一个盒子并理解它。你的目标是选择一个盒子并超越它。”

;

;莫卡说，他希望能够教计算机用他的技术创造有趣的新设计。但 Vejdemo-Johansson 认为计算机无法实现这一目标。计算机善于遵守规则；莫卡很擅长打破它们。 “你有一个完整的;世界模型;，”Vejdemo-Johansson说。 “你已经了解了你已经磨练了五十多年的时间，了解你周围的世界是如何存在的，以及你如何与它互动。”

;他引用了莫卡的闪闪发光的结，它可以支撑一个像硬币一样闪亮的物体。人工智能可能不知道原创性和古怪性之间的区别；它可能会通过尝试插入汽车的车轮或打领带的人的手腕来重复闪闪发光的结。即使人类反馈将其推向优雅的结，算法也可能很难找到一个。 Vejdemo-Johansson 说，在所有可能的结的空间中，“我的直觉是，有趣的纽带太稀疏了。”最优雅的结可能是远离丑陋的一步，或者只是解开。

;

;“这本书将被称为‘一百万种打结的方法’，”莫卡说。 “我没有科学证据来证实这一点。”

;

;“这很容易，”Vejdemo-Johansson 回答道。他的论文描述了 25 万节；如果选择添加莫卡的一些动作，这个数字就会远远超过一百万。 “一行证明，”他说。这两个人现在是数学合作者。

;球体

;我询问了其他几位数学家他们对 Mocka 结的看法。当宾夕法尼亚州乌尔辛努斯学院的拓扑学家尼古拉斯·斯科维尔 (Nicholas Scoville) 在 Zoom 上加入我时，他所系的领带采用了莫卡的一种技术：褶皱形成了三个小杯子，就好像这个结是用来接住面包屑的。斯科维尔后来看了莫卡的书，思考如果莫卡的各种折叠动作与维德莫-约翰逊的语法结合起来会发生什么。 “我无法想象这会产生多少新的领带结，”他说。

;

;华盛顿与李大学的数学家伊丽莎白·丹尼 (Elizabeth Denne) 告诉我，她喜欢结，因为普通人可以与他们。 “很容易告诉你我在做什么，”她告诉我。 “但是你需要的数学可以非常全面。”可以使用几何、代数、组合学和分析来研究纽结。当 Denne 和两名学生发布 ;关于芬克和毛的八十五节的论文;，在 2021 年，他们证明了关于它们的一些事情 - 例如，它们是素数结。 （这意味着，如果你将它们切成两半，你将留下一个平凡的结和一个重要的结。）

;

;在视频通话中，丹尼从莫卡的书中挑选了一个结。 “鲍里斯的工作就像是一锅鱼，”她告诉我。 “我不认为这个人是巅峰，因为他的事情就像是，;垃圾;。”她特别指着结的一处。 “他在这里打了半个弯。然后他将其贯穿起来。他在旁边做的这件事——那是一个单独的结，就在那里。所以这不是一个优质领带结。”至少，她不这么认为。

;
;
;

;需要更多的数学技巧来描述 Mocka 的艺术。结理论通常将绳子视为一维，但绳子也有宽度，这使得它们更像丝带而不是线。因此，领带中的扭曲可能具有数学意义，就像它对称为莫比乌斯带的著名拓扑物体的意义一样。丹尼专门研究物理结理论，该理论考虑了现实生活中丝带或绳索等物体的宽度或体积，但她告诉我，这样做“真的非常非常困难”。 “这几乎就像你的日常结太难了。”没有人能够设法增加摩擦力。墨洛温王朝将不得不等待进一步的研究。

;

;我想知道领带结的数学是否可以应用于其他任何地方——其他科学领域，或者现实世界。 “我不知道领带结之外还有什么用途，”丹尼说。 “但是，没有人认为折纸有用。”她引用了受折叠纸启发的;NASA;技术，例如在太空中展开的星光阴影。当代物理学家将纽结理论应用于量子力学和粒子穿过时空的蜿蜒路径。在湍流流体和电磁场中观察到了结。化学家想象分子结成结来产生特定的性质。生物物理学家有时会谈论 DNA 的拓扑结构，其双链的行为有点像打结的丝带。拓扑异构酶有助于解开它们。

;

;不过，从另一种意义上来说，数学与领带有一些共同点：这只是我们喜欢做的事情，无论它是否具有功能性。有时，人类追求事物的原因很简单：它们很复杂，或违反直觉，或美丽。对领带结的研究可以像结本身一样异想天开和复杂，这可能就足够了。 “我对此感兴趣，因为我对有趣和奇怪的事情感兴趣，”Vejdemo-Johansson 告诉我。

;两个月之前，我决定自学三位一体结。我打开衣柜，挑选了一条条纹领带，希望它能凸显结的独特设计。然后我站在镜子前，我的笔记本电脑离我几步远，开始模仿在线教程。在我最初的几次尝试中，我失败了。我什至不确定自己是否成功，直到我拉动并整理好结。

;

;有几次，我尝试发明一个结。有很多摆弄和捏造的事情。很难说一个动作从哪里结束，另一个动作从哪里开始。从这个意义上说，领带看起来更像是培乐多而不是乐高积木。然而，稍微收紧或放松一下就能让杂乱的排列突然变得对称。这个过程让我想起了数学家谈论他们的研究的方式。有时，你从一个目的地开始，需要弄清楚到达那里的路；有时，你只是从一个想法开始，结果却出乎意料。你迷失了道路，原路返回，然后再次找到它。当你迈出最后一步时，你手中就握着一些新的东西：一个漂亮、严密的证据。

;;去年，内森·菲尔德 (Nathan Fielder) 引发了; ;激烈; ;关于道德和真实性的辩论;与“;《排练》;”——一部 HBO 的“纪录片喜剧”，我觉得既引人入胜又令人震惊——所以感觉他第一次涉足有剧本的电视节目都关注相同的主题。 ;《诅咒》;将于今晚在 Showtime 首映，讲述了一场“慈善”翻屋节目的拍摄过程，已婚的搭档主持人阿舍尔（菲尔德饰）和惠特尼·西格尔（艾玛·斯通饰）取代了苦恼的人。新墨西哥州埃斯帕尼奥拉的房产拥有环保且价格明显更高的房屋。婚姻、拍摄和社区中不可避免地会出现紧张气氛。该剧一半是讽刺，一半是心理恐怖，揭露了电视真人秀令人作呕的诡计和白人自由主义慷慨的局限性。尽管西格尔夫妇坚称他们的项目只会让居民受益，但他们所宣称的价值观很快就被一个非政治性的网络、一个不道德的生产者以及他们对自己如何被看待的焦虑所掩盖。试播几分钟后，有人将薄荷醇吹入癌症患者的眼睛中，模拟感激的泪水。

;
;;
;

;一段陷入困境的浪漫史和制作过程也是大卫·阿吉米 (David Adjmi) 在剧作家地平线 (Playwrights Horizo​​ns) 的出色新剧;“立体声”;的核心。故事发生在十九世纪七十年代的加利福尼亚州，讲述了一支乐队在一张专辑的创作过程中崩溃的故事。戴安娜（莎拉·皮金饰）是一位野心勃勃的歌手，正处于个人事业的风口浪尖。她的长期男友兼主音吉他手彼得（汤姆·佩辛卡饰）不断地为她和其他人发出残酷的音符。 《立体声》和《诅咒》一样，都以自私、善变的角色为基础。但西格尔夫妇的作品从一开始就令人反感，阿吉米却相信所有这些痛苦所产生的艺术。他认为，音乐值得深夜、痴迷地重拍、以及一路上破裂的关系。在《诅咒》的愤世嫉俗之后，主角们一心掩盖自己的真实本性，看到乐队成员为真实的东西而奋斗，令人感动。

;巴勃罗·毕加索逝世五十周年激发了许多大型或深入的展览的灵感。佩斯画廊为庆祝活动做出了杰出的贡献，;“毕加索：14本素描本”;很长，研究了 1900 年至 1959 年间大师的手的演变。这是一个一站式商店，可以买到甚至非爱好者们可以滔滔不绝地讲述（乐器、情妇、锯齿状裸体、眼神邪恶的公牛），当然，还有一些上世纪最好的绘画。在 1924 年完成的宏伟的《女人头像》（如图）中，摇摆不定、任性的印度墨水线条融合成某种坚硬且不可避免的东西——如果毕加索崇拜和毕加索仇恨的对立崇拜让你感到厌烦，那就寻找像这样的图像晒太阳。—;;Jackson Arn;（佩斯；截至 12 月 22 日。）;;

;歌剧

;丹尼尔·卡坦 (Daniel Catán) 的;《佛罗伦萨与亚马逊》;是一部无比可爱的歌剧，毫不掩饰地拥抱了后浪漫主义音乐语言大气的木管乐器、颤动的弦乐和闪亮的高音。有些人可能会称其为 1996 年作品的倒退，但它对普契尼的借鉴，很适合讲述 1900 世纪初一位渴望的女主角的故事。当角色们乘坐穿越亚马逊河的河船前往巴西歌剧院时，令人陶醉的乐器音色组合表达了他们的愿望。 For the Met première, Ailyn Pérez, a soprano with an especially warm voice, stars as the titular diva, in a production directed by Mary Zimmerman and conducted by Yannick Nézet-Séguin.—;;Oussama Zahr; (Metropolitan Opera House; select dates Nov. 16-Dec. 14.);

;When ;Bob Dylan; gave his Nobel lecture, after being awarded the 2016 prize for literature, he implored people to take in his lyrics as they were intended: by listening, on record or in concert, not by reading. He quoted Homer, and he pointed to his songs as vehicles for storytelling. “I've searched the world over for the Holy Grail / I sing songs of love—I sing songs of betrayal,” he croaks on “False Prophet,” a single he performs on his “Rough and Rowdy Ways” tour, which comes to New York City this month. His album of the same name, from 2020, is full of glorious Americana, with scenes—from Key West to the Rubicon, the grassy knoll to the city of God—etched by his seasoned delivery. As he puts it, he sings songs of experience, which bear in them not only stories from his travels but the hallowed history of every time he's performed.—;;Sheldon Pearce; (Kings Theatre, Nov. 14-15; Beacon Theatre, Nov. 16.);

;Dance
;
;;
;

;In Rudyard Kipling's “The Jungle Book,” a young boy raised by a family of wolves must choose between life in the animal kingdom and a return to the human world. The British dancer-choreographer Akram Khan posits a different question in his ;“Jungle Book reimagined”:; Is there even a place for humans on a planet they have damaged to the point of near-collapse? Through a mix of audio, animation, and dance, Khan has created a fable about the moral and physical costs of environmental destruction. The protagonist, Mowgli, a girl who has lost her parents to rising seas, is both protected and challenged by the animals who save her, whose thoughts are heard in voice-over.—;;Marina Harss; (Rose Theatre; Nov. 16-18.);

;
;
;Art
;

;In recent years, the Brooklyn Museum has organized shows around non-fine-artist superstars of varying quality and relevance. ;“Spike Lee: Creative Sources”; comprises some four hundred and fifty objects from the director's collection, including the original draft of the screenplay for his first masterpiece, “Do the Right Thing”; a Richard Avedon photograph of Malcolm X; a letter from Barack Obama; and one of Prince's guitars. Indulgent? Sure, but a messy, risky too-muchness has always been one of Lee's strengths, and it seems appropriate here—you come away overloaded but still eager to rewatch the films. As long as the museum is in the habit of giving the reins to celebrities, it might as well give them to Brooklyn's best.—;Jackson Arn (Brooklyn Museum; through Feb. 4.);

;In ;“May December,”; Todd Haynes dramatizes the complex connection between an actress, Elizabeth (Natalie Portman), and a woman, Gracie (Julianne Moore), whom she's planning to portray in a movie. Gracie and her husband, Joe (Charles Melton), are pariahs in their home town of Savannah. Their relationship began when he was just out of seventh grade and she was in her thirties; she was imprisoned, and after her release they married. Now, twenty years later, they have three nearly grown children, and they're desperate for empathetic understanding. Enter Elizabeth, who insinuates herself into the family, gains information—and possibly disinformation—about the couple's troubled life, and exhibits artistic intentions as dubious as her ethical judgment. Haynes deftly sketches a tangle of manipulations and power plays and, along the way, offers a useful reminder: when Hollywood comes for your life story, run.—;;Richard Brody; (Opening Nov. 17 in theatres and streaming on Netflix starting Dec. 1.);

;Off Broadway
;

;Jerome Weidman and the composer Harold Rome's garment-district musical, from 1962—thoughtfully reshaped by Weidman's librettist son, John, and directed by Trip Cullman—feels like being walloped by a roll of velvet. I mean that admiringly: when slippery Harry Bogen (Santino Fontana) takes advantage of his doting mama (Judy Kuhn), his adoring sweetheart (Rebecca Naomi Jones), and his trusting business partner (Adam Chanler-Berat) to get ahead, it ;should; feel like a slug in the gut. ;“I Can Get It For You Wholesale”; is not just a rogue's tale; it's also a labor-movement cri de coeur. Julia Lester, playing Harry's secretary, belts “Miss Marmelstein,” the song that first made Barbra Streisand famous, but it's Lester's glass-shattering “What Are They Doing to Us Now?” that will stamp the price of unregulated, unrepentant capitalism right onto your quaking spirit.—;;Helen Shaw; (Classic Stage Company; through Dec. 17.);

;Pick Three

;;;

;;The staff writer ;Vinson Cunningham; shares current obsessions.;

;;

;;1.; ;Best cinematic interior design:; The more I think about Sofia Coppola's new film, ;“Priscilla,”; about the gilded cage inhabited by Priscilla Presley in her world-famous marriage to Elvis, the more I am enthralled and—reluctantly—seduced by its attention to sumptuous surfaces. Elvis's heavily brocaded bedroom, and the over-the-top beauty of the Presley home in Memphis, Tennessee, is a harrowing metaphor for the claustrophobic effects of patriarchy and the subtle encroachments of abuse.

;
;
;

;;2.; ;Best world-spanning exhibition:; The MacArthur “genius”-grant recipient ;An-My Lê; is one of my favorite artists in any medium. (She is also, I should admit, a friend.) Her photographs inspire deep contemplation at the crossroads of fiction and reënactment, politics and fantasy, the displacements of war and the feelings of home. Her truly epic career retrospective at ;MOMA;—curated by Roxana Marcoci and Caitlin Ryan—spans, with rare rigor and rarer beauty, post-Trump America, postwar Vietnam, the Civil War, and the civic disruptions that follow the making of a nation.

;
;;
;

;;3.; ;Best album bridging today's music to nineties R. & B.:; I have been hopelessly obsessed with ;“The Love Album: Off the Grid,”; the new record by the mega-producer Diddy (formerly known as Puff Daddy), since its September release. The East Coast R. & B. that I grew up with—by such artists as Carl Thomas, Faith Evans, and Mary J. Blige—was shepherded into being, in large part, by Diddy. Now he's made a swoon-inducing, lovesick album that looks back at those sources, infusing them with new voices and fresh sounds.

;Donald Trump often takes the breath away with his defiance of the basic norms of American public life. (See: ;January 6th;.) But sometimes it's the smaller encroachments on decency that serve as a reminder of how far outside the bounds he operates. “Can you control your client?” Judge Arthur Engoron demanded of Trump's lawyer, during the former President's ;testimony on Monday; in Manhattan, where he stands ;accused; of running a fraudulent business in the state of New York. “This is not a political rally. This is a courtroom.” Later, after yet another Trump soliloquy in response to a yes-or-no question, Engoron repeated his entreaty. “I beseech you,” the judge said, “to control him if you can.”

;

;Of course, seven years and five months into Trump's political career, we know by now that there is no controlling Trump. And yet, exactly a year before Election Day, that rogue defendant in the dock is not only the presumptive Republican nominee but ;running in a dead heat; with Joe Biden nationally and, if the shock poll that came out ;in the ;Times;; a day before Trump's testimony is to be believed, ahead of him in five of six must-win battleground states. Trump's lawyer Christopher Kise even bragged about this in Engoron's courtroom, citing the poll as he referred to his client as “the future President of the United States.” The poll's release quickly sent Democratic Washington into a vaporous state of preëmptive blame-gaming about the status of the race: ;It's Biden's age;. ;It's his campaign;. ;It's the media's fault;. ;It's all of the above.; One anonymous sniper told NBC News that the campaign needed a “;defibrillator;.” The former Obama adviser David Axelrod even kinda, sorta, maybe ;suggested; that Biden should consider stepping aside as the Party's 2024 standard-bearer. The White House sought to downplay the fuss as the inevitable outcry from the Party's large class of professional “bed wetters.” Perhaps, one Democratic strategist insisted, albeit anonymously, to ;the Washington ;Post;;, some bed-wetting was in order: “We should be terrified about what might happen.”

;

;The panicky news cycle was interrupted when Tuesday's off-year election results came in: a ;big win; for abortion rights in the increasingly red state of Ohio; a victory for the incumbent Democratic governor, Andy Beshear, in the solidly red state of Kentucky; a Democratic state House pickup in Virginia that looked to spoil the national aspirations of its Republican governor, Glenn Youngkin. Inevitably, team Biden claimed vindication. “Across the country tonight, democracy won and MAGA lost,” the President posted on social media. “Voters vote. Polls don't.”

;

;Days later, though, I'm still struggling to understand the chill-out, everything's-going-according-to-the-plan spin. I know that the spinners have a job to do and that some amount of self-soothing is required in these stressful times. But still, whichever individual poll you choose to believe or not, the data point overwhelmingly to Biden sitting at near-historic lows in popularity and being essentially tied with Trump, a man who is running on an explicit platform of revenge, retribution, and Constitution-termination. As for the predictive power of off-year elections, it's best to remember that the big victory in Virginia amounted to Democrats narrowly holding onto the state Senate—they actually lost a seat—and gaining the state House with a net pickup of three seats, in a state that Biden won against Trump in 2020 by more than ten points. If Democrats had received nineteen hundred fewer votes in a single Virginia Senate district and eight hundred fewer in a single Virginia House district, they wouldn't have won full control of either chamber. That's hardly the reassurance that the Party craves looking ahead to 2024.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Besides, Biden is up against not just electoral math but human psychology. There were plenty of reasonable theories of how and why Trump's appeal would fade once he left the White House and the full folly of his unprecedented effort to block the 2020 election results was revealed. But those theories have not panned out. Instead, Trump has, after four criminal indictments and multiple civil proceedings, such as the trial in New York, opened up such a wide lead against his GOP opponents that watching ;Wednesday night's debate; among the also-rans seemed like an incredible waste of time for any but the most masochistic of Republican viewers. I watched; it was eminently skippable. The short version is that Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina who served as Trump's Ambassador to the United Nations, continued to embarrass her rivals with sharp retorts, offering voters an almost anachronistic attachment to the hawkish foreign policy of the pre-Trump GOP and a reluctance to fully disavow the ex-President she is ostensibly running against. It said everything about this Republican field that, when invited to condemn Trump in the debate's opening question, four of the five candidates onstage offered varying critiques of his electability and conservative record without getting to the heart of the matter. Ron DeSantis complained about Trump not building his wall. Tim Scott lamented his lack of appeal to independents. Haley said Trump wasn't the right President for our political moment. And then there was Vivek Ramaswamy, who demanded that the moderator apologize for even asking such a question.

;
;
;

;More revealing—and far more relevant, given where the race stands—was Trump's own rally that evening, in Hialeah, Florida, which took place as his latest act of counterprogramming during the Republican debate. While talking for well more than an hour, he fulminated about 2024 in nearly apocalyptic terms (“our final battle”) and added a gruesome note that I hadn't heard before about the “liars and leeches” who have been “sucking the life and blood” out of the country. He portrayed himself—and his followers—as victims of a “police state.” (Consistency is never a hallmark of Trump's attacks; he also called Biden's government a feckless “banana republic.”) And he offered plenty of additional fodder to those who think that he, not Biden, has aged out of the Presidency, like when he praised Kim Jong Un, North Korea's dictatorial leader, and mixed up the population size of North Korea with that of China.

;On Thursday, in an ;interview with Univision;, Trump again made explicit what is often implicit in his vengeance-fuelled campaign: his willingness to use the justice system to go after his opponents if he is returned to the White House. Any other prospective President would have denied with all possible force a recent ;Washington ;Post; report; that Trump has already demanded that his aides make plans to target some former advisers who have become public critics, including his former chief of staff John Kelly, former Attorney General Bill Barr, and former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Milley. Instead, Trump all but confirmed the story when he told the Spanish-language network that he would use the courts against his political rivals. “If I happen to be President and I see somebody who's doing well and beating me very badly, I say, 'Go down and indict them,' ” Trump told Univision. “他们就会破产。 They'd be out of the election.”

;

;There should be no surprise in this, of course. When Trump ran in 2016, he promised to jail his opponent, Hillary Clinton, and laughed and cheered and egged on his crowds when they chanted, “Lock her up! Lock her up!”

;

;In an appearance this week on “The View,” Clinton compared Trump to Adolf Hitler, who was, she noted, “duly elected” before he dismantled Germany's democracy and turned himself into a dictator. Her main point—and it bears endless repetition between now and whatever awaits us next November—is that Trump has clearly spelled out exactly how he plans to go after core tenets of American democracy. There is no mystery here. “Trump is telling us what he intends to do,” Clinton said. “Take him at his word. The man means to throw people in jail who disagree with him, shut down legitimate press outlets, do what he can to literally undermine the rule of law and our country's values.”

;

;It's worth noting that Clinton made those comments ;before; Trump's incendiary interview. He's said it all before; he'll say it all again. The question, with one year left on the clock, is: Who's listening? ♦

;从去年春天开始，志愿者在俄亥俄州各地呈扇形分布 —;在农贸市场、啤酒吧、超市、运动场;——试图说服50万人签署请愿书，以在11月的投票中获得保障堕胎权的宪法修正案。一天下午，在辛辛那提的丝绸之路纺织公司，在针线活书的书架上，两名银发志愿者坐在一张桌子旁，桌子上贴着写着“OHI-Roe”和“Restore Roe”的贴纸，这两个座右铭旨在表明拟议的修正案将绝不要激进。当一位组织者走进来时，一名志愿者喊道：“我们度过了非常愉快的一天！”书中有几十个签名，还有数十万个签名。近期目标是;废除一项法律;，由俄亥俄州共和党人通过并签署，目前正在接受共和党控制的州最高法院的审查，该法案在大约六周后禁止几乎所有堕胎，强奸或乱伦也不例外。

;

;周二，最初结果不确定的草根倡议变成了自;最高法院的多布斯判决;，2022 年 6 月，;推翻;罗伊诉韦德案所保障的权利。在一个长期由共和党人主导的州，超过两百万人支持了一项宪法修正案，声称“每个人都有权做出和执行自己的生育决定”。该修正案与罗伊法案一样，允许州政府仅在胎儿存活后才限制堕胎，除非医生认为有必要保护母亲的生命或健康，该修正案通过了超过 13 个百分点。公平项目（Fairness Project）的执行董事凯利·霍尔（Kelly Hall）在红州和紫州推动进步投票措施，她告诉我，“俄亥俄州的胜利确实告诉我们堕胎权运动中的所有人，这几乎在任何地方都是可能的。”

;

;俄亥俄州是今年唯一一个选民对堕胎权进行赞成或反对投票的州，但该州和其他地方的结果提供了新的证据，表明该问题可能会在 2024 年对民主党有利。在弗吉尼亚州，痛斥;格伦·扬金<的反堕胎政策的民主党人<共和党州长保留了州参议院的领导权，并赢得了众议院的控制权。在肯塔基州，民主党州长安迪·贝希尔（Andy Beshear）击败共和党总检察长;丹尼尔·卡梅伦;赢得连任，他支持该州;近乎全面禁令; 关于堕胎。在宾夕法尼亚州，民主党增加了在州最高法院的多数席位，;选举丹·麦卡弗里;，他将堕胎作为其十年任期竞选活动的核心部分。

;

;结果还表明，一些共和党人试图缓和自己的立场，但支持堕胎的选民并未被说服。杨金经常被认为是潜在的总统候选人，他曾说过“生命从受孕开始”，并且他将签署任何法案“;幸福快乐地保护生命;。”但是，在弗吉尼亚州（最后一个广泛堕胎受到保护的南方州）的竞选期间，Youngkin 的政治行动委员会花费了 140 万美元来分发 ;视频广告;宣称支持“合理的十五周限制”，但强奸、乱伦、和母亲的生命，但不适用于胎儿存在致命异常的情况。

;

;在俄亥俄州，堕胎权的支持者认为，该修正案有利于患者而不是政客，并且不仅保护堕胎方面的决定还包括避孕、生育治疗、流产护理和“继续怀孕”等基本卫生规定。他们强调，没有任何已知的医学理由可以限制堕胎，并将选择堕胎视为个人自由问题。周三，俄亥俄州生殖权利联盟联合主席劳伦·布劳维尔特 (Lauren Blauvelt) 表示，选民们“重新获得了在不受政府干预的情况下做出最个人决定的自由。”

;

;俄亥俄州 ;筹集资金和支出<他们向对手投入了数百万美元，并建立了一个跨越党派和地域的联盟，并得到工会、牧师和积极进取的妇女团体的支持。卡马拉·哈里斯，;格雷琴·惠特默;，约翰·传奇 (John Legend) 出面支持这项名为第一期的投票措施。“他们告诉我们，我们是少数派，”邻国密歇根州的民主党州长惠特默在一次虚拟集会上表示，该州于 2022 年批准了一项类似的修正案。 “我们不是。我们是多数。”

;
;
;

;在过去十五个月里，选民在投票问题上保护堕胎权;连续六次;，在堪萨斯州、蒙大拿州、佛蒙特州、加利福尼亚州、密歇根州和肯塔基州。俄亥俄州在等待州最高法院对为期六周的禁令进行审查之前，堕胎仍然合法。为了赢得俄亥俄州的胜利，堕胎权支持者必须克服决心打破堕胎连胜纪录的共和党人的伎俩。

;去年春天，支持堕胎的团体开始收集签名国务卿弗兰克·拉罗斯 (Frank LaRose) 成功推动了 8 月份的公投，将宪法修正案通过的门槛提高到简单多数的 60%，而这一直是俄亥俄州的标准 ;自 1912 年;。就在几个月前，他帮助说服共和党主导的立法机构废除了八月份的特别选举，该选举历来投票率很低，;称它们;“对我们州的公民健康来说是坏消息。”起初，他;坚称;改变规则是只是一个“好政府”的问题。但是，他在向塞尼卡县的支持者发表讲话时表示，这一策略“百分百是为了将激进的堕胎修正案排除在我们的宪法之外”。选民;拒绝了这一举措;提高了十四个百分点。 （如果通过了，设定了百分之六十的门槛，周二的宪法修正案就会失败。）

;相反，董事会以 3 比 2 的投票结果撰写了一份长度大致相同的“摘要”。委员会主席是拉罗斯，他说他对文本进行了“广泛的工作”，其中包括将“胎儿”替换为“未出生的孩子”，并以最不利于堕胎权努力的方式制定修正案。摘要没有明确指出该修正案的具体语言，即国家可以禁止在胎儿存活后堕胎（生命和健康除外），而是声称该修正案“始终允许未出生的孩子在怀孕的任何阶段进行堕胎，无论其情况如何”。生存能力”，如果主治医生认为有必要的话。俄亥俄州生殖权利联合会称这些变化是“他们自己选出的官员赤裸裸地试图误导。”

;

;作为回应，红葡萄酒和蓝组织的领导人做出了回应，该组织动员郊区妇女为进步主义组织工作原因，召开了一次紧急培训会议，以帮助志愿者向选民传达拟议修正案的实际内容。 “只是将全文呈现在尽可能多的人面前，”俄亥俄州团队的项目总监 Jen Perez 说。例如，反对者认为，如果未成年子女怀孕，该修正案将消除父母的权利，因为文本规定“每个人”都有权选择堕胎。然而，;法律专家的共识;是：未成年人的权利可以受到限制。该联盟认为，该修正案实际上加强了父母的权利，他们可以选择帮助孩子选择如何处理怀孕。根据这项为期六周的法律，即使是遭受性侵犯后需要堕胎的孩子也必须离开该州才能堕胎。这种情况发生在去年，当时俄亥俄州一名十岁的强奸受害者被要求前往印第安纳州接受治疗，这起案件引起了全国关注。

;

;在这样的故事中，民意调查显示了一致的支持在堕胎问题上，俄亥俄州共和党州长迈克·德温 (Mike DeWine) 在 2019 年签署了这项为期六周的法律，他在周二投票前的几周内，试图像杨金一样，对反堕胎运动表现出更加温和的态度。他说宪法修正案是一个“激进的提议”，并且在广为人知的三十秒广告中，他和他的妻子弗兰将修正案反对者视为合理的一方。 “无论我们走到哪里，”州长说，“人们都告诉我们他们对第一个问题感到困惑。”弗兰·德温接着说，该修正案将允许“怀孕期间的任何时间”堕胎。 （广告 ;没有通过事实核查人员的审查;。）绝大多数选民有不同的看法，这向堕胎权倡导者发出了一个信号，他们可能会在明年的投票中提出类似的倡议在密苏里州、佛罗里达州和亚利桑那州等州。

;

;在俄亥俄州，共和党领导人表示，周二的结果并不是他们努力的终点。马特·霍夫曼，参议院议长，;预测;“投票活动的旋转门废除或取代第一期。”投票前，我采访了俄亥俄州生命权组织主席迈克·戈尼达基斯 (Mike Gonidakis)。 ;他为多布斯判决的那天欢呼;，当时一位联邦法官在俄亥俄州 ;允许该州的“心跳”法律生效。当我上周与戈尼达基斯交谈时，他并不是在谈论他更喜欢的全面禁令，而是在寻找他所谓的“共同点”。他说，堕胎反对者有责任找到一个成功的方案。 “我们必须回到投票，”他说，“带着一些能通过的东西。” ♦
